title: 114_s1388
content: The Act titled "Cuba Normalization Accountability Act of 2015" includes definitions in Section 2. The "Cuba Normalization Accountability Act of 2015" defines key terms related to confiscated property, Cuban assets control regulations, and the economic embargo of Cuba. The "Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000" defines terms related to export administration regulations and United States nationals. The "Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000" defines terms related to export administration regulations and United States nationals. SEC. 3. SENSE OF CONGRESS. Congress finds that President Obama announced a plan to revise US policy towards Cuba, easing restrictions on travel and trade. The revisions were made through the Department of the Treasury and Commerce, implementing changes to licensing authorities under existing regulations. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 still prohibits the full removal of the economic embargo. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 prohibits full removal of the economic embargo on Cuba. It includes provisions for discretionary licensing authority, such as considering the return of property to US citizens taken by the Cuban Government since January 1, 1959. Section 206 of the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 outlines requirements for establishing a democratically elected government in Cuba, including the return of property to US citizens taken by the Cuban Government since January 1, 1959. Section 103 prohibits US nationals or agencies from providing financing knowingly. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 prohibits US nationals or agencies from financing transactions involving property confiscated by the Government of Cuba from US nationals. Congress believes that restrictions on travel and trade with Cuba should not be eased until certain conditions are met, including the return of confiscated property and protection of human rights in Cuba. SEC. 4 of the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 addresses the plan for resolving outstanding claims related to property confiscated by the Government of Cuba. The President is prohibited from easing restrictions on travel or trade with Cuba until a plan is submitted to Congress to resolve claims related to confiscated property by the Cuban government. This plan aims to ensure that property taken from US nationals after January 1, 1959, is returned or compensated for. The President must assess the impact of easing restrictions on claims related to confiscated property by the Cuban government before submitting a plan to Congress.
